awd_titl_txt: I-Corps:  Novel Adsorbents for Water Treatment
awd_abstract_narration:
The proposed technology was developed in the NSF I/UCRC for Water and Environmental Technology (WET), and involves novel adsorbent material that can be used to efficiently remove organic contaminants and suspended particles from water. After use, it can be regenerated in-situ and its capacity to remove contaminants is recovered. The material can then be reused for water treatment. The proposed work will address the challenges identified for the commercialization of this technology, including a pilot scale demonstration. 

The proposed technology would provide a cost efficient and environmentally sustainable solution to treat water and wastewater. Unlike other processes, such as activated carbon adsorption and air stripping which are widely used in the industry for water and wastewater treatment, the proposed technology does not create a secondary waste since the adsorbed contaminants are destroyed. The proposed work would be of interest to municipal water and wastewater utilities, manufacturing industry that need to treat their wastewater, companies that market point-of-use water filters and companies that provide water treatment solutions. In addition, the project would advance the state of the art in environmental science and engineering fields by providing a new adsorbent material for the removal of organic contaminants and suspended particles from water. Activated carbon (AC) has been designated as the Best Available Technology (BAT) by the US EPA for the removal of organic contaminants from water, and is very widely used world-wide; hence, there is tremendous market opportunity for the proposed technology as a superior replacement to AC.
org_dir_long_name: Directorate for Technology, Innovation, and Partnerships

inst.org_lgl_bus_name: TEMPLE UNIVERSITY-OF THE COMMONWEALTH SYSTEM OF HIGHER EDUCATION

por.por_cntn:
A water treatment technology, with lineage to the National Science Foundation, was examined for its commercialization.  This technology involves a novel, regenerable and reusable adsorbent filter to decontaminate water.  The adsorbent has been tested and verified for the removal of certain organic contaminants from water.  For the commercialization of this technology, there are technical and business related challenges.  Some of these challenges include development and validation of value proposition, identification of customers, determining the various market channels, the necessary supply chain and partners, and others. 

Under the ICORPs Grant, various technology commercialization aspects were explored.  The research team performed over 100 interviews of professionals in the water industry to learn more about technology commercialization aspects.  These interviews focused on Customer discovery, value proposition, supply chain, how to get and keep the customers, market development, and other aspects of technology commercialization. It was a great learning experience, and this program was very useful to understand the details of how to commercialize the technology and starting a new business.  Consequently, a company was established in 2014 to commercialize the technology.   The technology would provide the society a water filter to remove organic contaminants from water in a cost effective way, and reuse the filter.  


Last Modified: 03/12/2016
Modified by: Rominder Suri
